awd_titl_txt: A Comparative Life Cycle Assessment of Commercialized Hydroponics vs. Aquaponics for Vegetable Production in New Jersey
awd_abstract_narration:
1946746 (Mu). This project will conduct a comparative Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) to quantify resource use and environmental and human health impacts of vegetable production with two water-based farming techniques in five commercialized facilities (three for hydroponics and two for aquaponics) built in densely populated areas in New Jersey. The research team will undertake both on-site data collection and software modeling in conducting LCA. The scope for analysis will cover all the impacts in facility establishment, vegetable production, and upstream supply chains. The project is expected to improve understanding of hydroponics and aquaponics, and provide recommendations to improve technologies and guidance to select among various farming techniques. The study has the potential to lead to greater application of water-based farming in urban areas and add another source of food supply to city dwellers that have limited access to fresh and nutritious foods. Increased applications could help reduce hunger and increase food diversity, independence, and resiliency of cities. In addition, the project will extend research on sustainable farming and provide a learning practicum for students.

The project targets to: 1) Establish an inventory of resources used, vegetables produced, and emissions from the facilities; 2) Analyze environmental and human health impacts of various vegetables produced and identify key factors that cause resource use and impacts; and, 3) Compare the LCA results and figure out how resource use and impacts are related to facility design, scale, and type of vegetable growing. Finally, the study will discuss how to improve hydroponic design and operation to reduce resource consumption and impacts, and create a general guide for cities, communities, and families to select water-based farming techniques according to varied locations, land and resource availability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Overview of the farms

The project directly hired 10 undergraduate students and involved 4 high school students working at the four farms, i.e., the Groundwork Elizabeth Farm (GWE), Sweetleaf Farm (SLF), and the Drop the Beet Farm/Little Box Farm (LBF), and the Kean Farm, installed with various water-based farming systems, including Nutrients film Technology (NFT) hydroponics, bucket dripping hydroponics, Deepwater hydroponics (DWH), and an aquaponics system with koi fish raising and a raft hydroponics for plant growing. Collectively, the project recorded a total of 651 harvests for 38 different plant types. For each location, we established the life cycle inventory (LCI) for each vegetable grown and conducted life cycle assesment (LCA) . A total of 647 LCIs were built, and 120 life cycle assessments (LCA) were conducted with SimaPro for the vegetables grown in different seasons. The LCA included both direct and indirect impacts of vegetables produced and assessed different impacts, such as climate change, eutrophication, ozone depletion, toxicity, land use, and water resource depletion.

Significant Results and Suggestions

With the data collected in farms and LCA results, the research team evaluated different water farming technology and suggested improvement areas to increase yields and reduce environmental impacts. We found that the plant growing and LCA results varied in terms of hydroponic design, plants, scales, seasons, and operation skills of the farmers. Some of our important findings included:

  • The NFT has higher yields with shorter growing cycles in compared with other hydroponic systems. However, it needs more care and energy and often is associated with plant death by sudden power outages or system leaks.
  • The raft aquaponics system and bucket deep water hydroponics system generally have fewer inputs than NFT in terms of per kg of plant produced. The aquaponics system,in particular, does not require any synthetic nutrients. Also, the system needs less care compared to the NFT.
  • The bucket dripping hydroponics and Deepwater hydroponics can be used for fruit growing, which provides a unique advantage over NFT and raft hydroponics.
  • Resource consumption is not varied significantly with different leafy vegetables, but the herbs, such as dill, basil, and cilantro, generally have higher resource uses.
  • Winter generally has the highest water use and energy consumption per kg of plant produced and the highest life cycle impacts. Spring and summer have relatively low inputs and life cycle impacts per kg of vegetable grown.
  • The greenhouse and electricity used for running the systems were two major inputs that caused the life cycle impacts. The propane used in winter for heating also contributed to life cycle impacts significantly.
  • The indirect (upstream) impacts, i.e., impacts to produce electricity and tap water, were higher than the system?s direct impacts. In particular, the life cycle of water use is 3-4 times that of direct water consumption.
  • Compared with soil-grown lettuce, many lettuces grown in aquaponics and hydroponics had lower life cycle impacts than lettuce grown in the heated greenhouse.

Based on our work, we suggest the following to improve hydroponic performance and reduce resource use:

  • A remote monitoring and auto-control system should be installed on the farm to prepare for power outrage, prevent plant death, and reduce electricity use.
  • The farm should cover the tanks and reservoirs containing nutrient solutions to save water consumption and prevent algae bloom in summer.
  • Incorporate organic nutrients (fish water, compost tea, biochar) to reduce synthetic nutrient consumption and promote organic plant production in hydroponics.

Important Outcomes

The research team has provided nine posters, three oral presentations, and five workshops to disseminate project results. One student presented a poster for the prestigious "Posters on the Hill, 2020." at Capitol Hill in Washington, DC. In addition, the project was presented to the American Center for Life Cycle Assessment conference, the largest professional organization on LCA in the U.S. The PI and Co-PI are currently working with students on three manuscripts to submit for peer review. Three of the students involved with this project found jobs in local hydroponic businesses. Another important outcome is that the President of Kean University allocated funds for the PI and Co-PI to build a hydroponic farm (Kean Farm) within a newly renovated greenhouse on campus in large part because of this project.

This project has promoted research on sustainable farming in urban areas. Our data enriched the current databases and can now provide references for future studies. The project can be used to guide farmers and communities to select among various farming techniques while considering location, scale, and resource availability. It will lead to more applications of water-based farming in urban areas and benefit the environment and the farming industries. The increased application of water-based agriculture will also add a new source of fresh food supply, shorten the food supply chain, reduce hunger, and increase food diversity, independence, and resiliency of cities.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2022
Modified by: Dongyan Mu

Overview of the farms

The raft aquaponics system and bucket deep water hydroponics system generally have fewer inputs than NFT in terms of per kg of plant produced. The aquaponics system,in particular, does not require any synthetic nutrients. Also, the system needs less care compared to the NFT.
The bucket dripping hydroponics and Deepwater hydroponics can be used for fruit growing, which provides a unique advantage over NFT and raft hydroponics.
Resource consumption is not varied significantly with different leafy vegetables, but the herbs, such as dill, basil, and cilantro, generally have higher resource uses.

A remote monitoring and auto-control system should be installed on the farm to prepare for power outrage, prevent plant death, and reduce electricity use.
The farm should cover the tanks and reservoirs containing nutrient solutions to save water consumption and prevent algae bloom in summer.
Incorporate organic nutrients (fish water, compost tea, biochar) to reduce synthetic nutrient consumption and promote organic plant production in hydroponics.


Important Outcomes

The research team has provided nine posters, three oral presentations, and five workshops to disseminate project results. One student presented a poster for the prestigious "Posters on the Hill, 2020." at Capitol Hill in Washington, DC. In addition, the project was presented to the American Center for Life Cycle Assessment conference, the largest professional organization on LCA in the U.S. The PI and Co-PI are currently working with students on three manuscripts to submit for peer review. The project can be used to guide farmers and communities to select among various farming techniques while considering location, scale, and resource availability. It will lead to more applications of water-based farming in urban areas and benefit the environment and the farming industries. The increased application of water-based agriculture will also add a new source of fresh food supply, shorten the food supply chain, reduce hunger, and increase food diversity, independence, and resiliency of cities.
